General -Purpose AI Code of Practice Commitment Areas EU AI Act February 2025 AI & Partners

Authors: Sean Donald John Musch, Michael Charles Borrelli

This document, published by AI & Partners, outlines the organization's commitment to defending and extending digital rights for users at risk globally, particularly in the context of the EU AI Act and its associated Code of Practice. AI & Partners employs a multi-faceted approach, combining direct technical support, policy engagement, global advocacy, grassroots professional services, regulatory interventions, and participation in industry groups like AI Commons. The report addresses key questions surrounding the General-Purpose AI Code of Practice, including defining these models, understanding systemic risk associated with them, and justifying the necessity of regulations. It represents a strategic effort to ensure responsible development and deployment of AI, safeguarding user rights and mitigating potential harms. The organization's activities are driven by a commitment to ethical AI practices and a proactive stance in shaping the future of AI governance. The document serves as a foundational resource for understanding AI & Partners' role in navigating the evolving landscape of AI regulation and promoting digital rights worldwide. The ‚Äòbest-efforts‚Äô disclaimer indicates that the information provided is based on the organization‚Äôs current understanding and assessment, highlighting the dynamic nature of the field. Contact information for Michael Charles Borrelli, the Director, is also provided for further inquiries.

Key Concepts:

  • AI & Partners' commitment to digital rights for vulnerable users globally.
  • The need for regulations concerning General-Purpose AI models.
  • Defining General-Purpose AI models and identifying those with systemic risk.
  • Code of Practice as a compliance benchmark
  • GPAI model providers' transparency commitments regarding documentation and disclosure of model details
  • Risk management frameworks for AI deployment
  • Investing in robust safety and security practices offers a competitive advantage.
  • GPAI models require governance risk mitigation commitments to address systemic risk.
  • Structured governance frameworks are necessary for GPAI providers to manage systemic risk.
